ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with this course compared to others you have taken was:
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
How would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other F&ES courses you have taken?
Given the course objectives, the level of intellectual challenge of the material covered was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Understanding of business and environment issues
Thinking creatively about a problem, thinking about levers of change & change agents, developing a business plan

narratives.question_text: How well did the knowledge, skills, and insights gained in this class align with your expectations?
comments: I thought there would be more structure to the class and more formal learning about the different wicked challenges, but I'm actually glad my expectations weren't met. What I gained from this class ended up being more valuable to me.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of the course and how could it be improved?
comments: More practical tools for business and the environment
Strengths: guest speakers (esp. Peter Boyd, Dan Gross), ideation & reframing & archetyping sessions Weaknesses: Roger Ibbottson's lecture, which didn't really add any value

narratives.question_text: What advice would you give to a student considering taking this class?
comments: Even if none of the challenges are directly related to the topics you're focusing on here at Yale, I still recommend taking this class to help you think through problems at the intersection of business & the environment. It'll give you the opportunity to think creatively about problems and come up with innovative solutions, which is not something you get to do in many other courses.
